Free Kings Manor bus

YUSU President Kallum Taylor has announced that a free bus service is to be established for those who have academic commitments at Kings Manor

Palestinian Society ratified

The Palestinian Solidarity Society has been ratified by YUSU after a long process of appeals

Langwith demands heating from Vice Chancellor

Students have recorded temperatures of sub-15 degrees Celsius

Hes East: the deal in depth

Josh Boswell analyses the sale of half of Goodricke and Langwith colleges to Evans Group

What is the difference between tax evasion and tax avoidance?

Tax evasion and tax avoidance can be easily be confused. Amy Blumsom looks at the difference between the two.

Tuition fees increasingly fund PS127m debt

The University has taken on more debt, and is relying more on students to fund its deficits. This is due to several changes in its financial position, including a significant decline in research income coinciding with an a large increase in debt.

Optimistic estimates for campus rooms takeup

The University is predicting an optimistic rise in students returning to campus accommodation, despite the number of empty rooms doubling over the past year. If the University's prediction is not accurate, then there could be an shortfall from the expected income generated from accommodation.

University misses class target

The University was 3.3per cent beneath its benchmark for the proportion of students falling in to the traditionally working class National Statistics Socio-Economic Classification (NS-SEC) groups 4-7, in the 2010/11 academic year.

Student satisfaction with library continues to rise

The recently published Library survey results of 2012 mark a further increase in satisfaction with the University library. On average, all sections of the survey marked a 7% improvement in satisfaction with the library as a whole since the survey was conducted in 2011.

Porters pledge

The University has announced that portering provision for the 2013 Christmas vacation will be increased. Standard service across all colleges will be extended up until Christmas Eve and Derwent College will now have 24 hour cover throughout the holidays.

New Willow withdrawn

Regency Restaurant, the subject of speculation for a new disco in York has withdrawn its license application to operate as an "entertainment facility". The application was met with immediate opposition from the local authorities.

YUSU submit boundary proposal

Cadan ap Tomos, YUSU Community Assembly chair, has submitted a proposal to the Local Government Boundary Commission for England (LGBCE) in reaction to YUSU's own submission. YUSU's final proposal states that it represents YUSU's collective position. Ap Tomos, however, fears that the submission "may be taken to represent student opinion, despite only neighbourhood reps having been consulted."

Students voice housing concerns

The University of York's Student Socialist Society has called a public meeting pressuring the University and City Council to improve housing standards, claiming that up to one hundred students could face eviction.

Living Wage set for referendum

A motion to start lobbying YUSU and the University to pay all staff the Living Wage, is to be put to a YUSU referendum

The first complete breakdown of Student Experience Report and YUSU accounts

Nouse has had an in-depth look at the York Student Experience report and YUSU's accounts from the past academic year

Reports of mental health issues double

By James Bithell

Statistics reveal that 1631 students were seen by the Open Door Team last year

GSA Chair denounces "undemocratic" Council

The Graduate Students' Association Council decided on Saturday to hold a by-election, after the chair denounced the GSA Council's proposals to appoint someone to the position of Academic Affairs Officer, rather than hold an election

"Tax haven" company in PS1.2m Hes East profit

The University is sharing profits on some of its most lucrative Heslington East halls of residence with a private company registered in the secretive tax haven of Jersey

In pictures: snow on campus

Nouse captures some scenic shots from around campus as the winter weather sets in

University Professor receives BRISMES award

The prominent Muslim feminist and peer was awarded the honor, after delivering the BRISMES Annual Lecture at LSE on Wednesday

Cash point for Hes East

The University has installed a cash point at the Glasshouse near Langwith College

Sexual harassment claims against 'Spotted' York

Amid sexual harassment claims, controversial Facebook page stops posting messages

University blamed for primary school closure

The University's expansion has been blamed for a fall in the student numbers at a local primary school

Cantor and York academics receive honours

Taylor hits out at "inadequate" Christmas porter service

Although there will be 24 hour portering on Heslington East and Halifax, around 550 students on the main campus will have just one member of staff to help them

Reports of mental health issues double

The most recent statistics reveal 1,310 students were seen in the 2010/11 academic year
